o4nN9N-HHB7dLdZ8AYCygA.text: This has been a firm, unwavering favourite of mine & my family'sfor many years now. It seems to be the 1st choice for any birthday or catch upas it manages to combine a sense of occasion without feeling stuffy orold. That said it has a wonderful, traditional feel thanks to theattention to detail that all the staff give as well as the actual decor. If youhave to wait in their small bar area for your table  it is never for long andthey mix a great drink so just relax and enjoy the whole experience. You canexpect the food to be spot on every time. My Godmother and I love this place asthey always have such a good fish selection on the menu. If you are luckyenough to be invited to the member bar and restaurant do go  the dark woodexterior is quiet unexpected after the bright light of the flower shop (whichis how we entered) and the lift that takes you to all floors and glassstaircase makes you feel a bit like the snow queen (or maybe the fact it waswinter and we were in arctic fox added to that!). For what it is prices arefair, I've eaten in ghastly places for a lot more. This place in not trying tobe anything more than it is  but that just happens to be a reallyfantastic and place for lunch or dinner.

5Uy98PpMwK8wwUz6mIdEaw.text: Utterly enchanting. If you ring up on the day and don't mind eating outside peak hours (so about 10) you'll be fine to get a table. This really is a lovely, good-humoured restaurant that doesn't take anything too seriously. The staff are excellent. If you've got a special occasion (or just want to chance booking a table), you'll have a lovely time. Foodwise, the much-vaunted shepherds pie is a bit so-so, but the bang bang chicken started is utterly sublime. If you like oysters, those are really good too, and the foie gras had my friend making all sorts of wrong sex faces for the duration, and thanking the chef afterwards. Every meal at The Ivy is special. It's like a glass of Champagne in itself.

LkJ0vD6menGSyb40POEhGA.text: This was our second visit to The Ivy. From the minute you step in the door you know you are somewhere special and you feel like a celebrity. Excellent service and food. Would recommend it to all my friends.

bAgmVr3TnW4m1kHAk9V1SA.text: Went here while on vacation in London. Service was really excellent , didn't wait for anything, the kind of place that folds your napkin for you when you go to the bathroom, excuse me 'the loo'. All our food was excellent, my wife loved the caviar especially. We went on a weekday evening and almost every man was in suit and tie and the females didn't skimp on the swank either. Great for people watching, I was expecting James Bond to make an appearance.

4qI1N043XLNwrCL52AS9Lg.text: Cannot fault this place. A lot of people complain that it's ordinary food they serve - rubbish! It does indeed serve some classic british foods, such as Shepherds pie - which by the way, is to die for, but it is all excellently prepared and served and have never had cause to complain about anything. The service is outstanding and the prices, although slightly on the high side, I still thought they were very reasonable for the quality of the food and the service. We wer £320 on our last visit. That was for 4 people having 2 courses and then another 3 having pudding, 2 bottles of wine, 2 bottles of water and 8 champagne cocktails.I didn't think it was over-expensive at all for the quality of food and service we received. Everyone from the doorman to the clockroom assistant to the bar staff and waiters were all excellent and extremely helpful and attentive. 5*

9fMEklmyg6ukUDr2rplmfw.text: What blew me away about this place was the service. It was really amazing- the kind of thing where your wine glass gets refilled and you don't even notice the waiter. By far one of the best service staff I have ever seen.Appetizers were excellent- I had foie gras and the girlfriend had the steak tartare. Mine was perfectly cooked and hers was perfectly seasoned.For the main course I fish and chips... I wanted to go for something fancier but I could not resist finding out what fish and chips could be like at one of London's best restaurants. They were very good, but I felt like I should have gone for something better. She had lamb which she said was excellent.The dessert was outstanding. Definitely try the dessert with frozen berries and melted white chocolate sauce.All in all for 2 people with appetizers, main course, one shared dessert and a bottle of wine cost around 120. Not somewhere I could afford every weekend but it was a lot more reasonable then I expected.so why only 4 stars? I thought the decor was a bit strange- it felt  to me like being in an old steakhouse. Also- the menu said no photographs which kind of irritated me. Not that I was going to go and take lots of photos of everyone, but maybe just one or two of ourselves to remember the occasion.

ba0lkdoUREirVAV5x_boMA.text: I was alittle spoiled when I sent cause my friends were friends with the owner/wait staff so it was very pleasant and comforting being there. I love the dining room. The mini bar in the "waiting" area was alittle slow and not exaclty the best drinks i've had, but the food and the bottle of wine we got was great and a great busy environement. I def think this is a place to go with a group of 3 or more. loved it.

DFa1pvPx0fcRrFH5oeQ-Tw.text: Go there expecting good food... and you'll be disappointed. Go there expecting to see A listers.. and you'll be disappointed. Go there with the view you'll maybe see Michael Winner and eat some mediocre food... and you'll get just that.The Ivy has really been the 'It' restaurant of the past few years. And maybe a few years ago it actually had to rely on the food rather than who dined there last week. I think that it's got a bit up itself, and unfortunately you'll ending up paying a lot for standard food.So what is good about this place? The service is good, however I'd expect if you're minted and shagging some footballer you'd get much more attention. The food is ok, but you can get much better for much MUCH less cash.I think a lot of people actually go there to feel a little bit famous for the night. When I went there were paps hanging around (so maybe there was some D Lister inside) but it did feel great for that split second when they thought I might have been a WAG or media-type and they got their cameras ready. Before they realised I was Miss Jo Bloggs and their attention returned to their fags and coffee.All in all, you have to go there just once, to say you've been, but don't expect great food, or great service, or to see a celeb and you'll be fine.

kD6Cy_Lt6P4kOuO8glK4TQ.text: Went here on a business dinner and had a rather positive experience.  Did not know that this "The Ivy" restaurant provided inspiration to the one back home in Los Angeles.. who knows that's what wikipedia stated.  Anyways, I ordered asian starters (above average) and Arctic Char for the main course.  I must say that was quite fabulous.  The restaurant was very lively for a Wednesday night, and the service was very attentive.  Would love a return visit.

9ZFXKyaPs4lw0D8mQF9qhA.text: Amazing continental British food, used to be "the place" to be seen out in London, great location if your going to a play, awesome food, great drink menu. Would give it 5 stars but the service was so-so for most of the meal. Food was excellent and atmosphere was electric.

RBmivBCQhRVD2IbHZudYCA.text: Summary based on 1 dinner:--exceptionally friendly service at the front end, just average or perhaps a bit less at table--representative food disappointingI came by myself without a booking and the very friendly and accommodating front end staff was able to get me a table with some time restrictions, which was very understandable and acceptable.Since this was my first time at the Ivy, I asked the waiter for some suggestions based on what regulars ask for time and again. Cost wasn't a particular consideration.  The waiter's recommendation of fish and chips was surprising, but since he appeared to understand what I was looking for, it seemed ok.Anyway, the food was ok, but nothing great. The waiter essentially disappeared and, though the restaurant wanted to turn the table over, it was a chore to get the check.I'll give the Ivy 3* because of the warm reception and since it's just one data point.

ARNobpQW_7swXgXCmg7ycg.text: I would thoroughly recommend this place  the service was terrific, the food was out of this world, and of course it's a great place to try some celebrity spotting!

PNNb_2zimDkaPuQ6jQPzIw.text: The Ivy was chalked up to me as a top-notch restaurant with wicked queues - people apparently have to make reservations months in advance just to be seated. There is a celebrity quotient here as well, but to be very honest...the food was not remarkable. As usual with British fare, the food was not seasoned well and was poorly executed. The wine list was quite nice, but I go to a restaurant to EAT - not to people watch.

iLT4Nn7cwd8SvNoxzoPIuQ.text: After reading several good reviews I decided to give The Ivy a go, and I wasn't disappointed. It is only a few minutes from Leicester square, so conveniently located. A previous reviewer said this was a good place to do some celebrity spotting, and when I visited there was a very famous celebrity (who shall remain nameless) on the next table, which was a nice bonus. Starters range from £7-15 (unless you fancy the caviar at £90!), and the mains include shellfish, fish, pasta and various meat dishes and range from around £11-40. I chose a glass of red wine, Bang Bang chicken followed by slow-roasted pork with mash and cabbage. The service was good, the food excellent, and the price around £34. I called early in the week and it was still busy: so if you definitely want to get in it would be better to book in advance.

Whk3nlxB8SsLtVigs0U8Bg.text: Thought it was time to review the old place as I have been a regular ( off and on) for years. The Ivy is interesting in that, they charge £17 for cottage pie...what pub would do that? Yes, this is not a pub - Its a restaurant resting firmly on its laurels and charging over the odds for everything.I have eaten here and have, on several occassions heard fellow diners comment on the tastlessness of the food BUT they still go, as I do. The place is timeless, annoying,pricey but I love it! Worth going early before the pre theatre rush.A treasure.

vW3y6OKHEpfzbB0iqU1xOA.text: The Ivy isn't just a restaurant, it's an experience. Sure, if you're trying to book a table for Friday or Saturday night, then you're in for a long wait. But lunchtimes, weekdays or even just walking in off the street will see you with a good chance of a table straight away. The food is aimed fairly and squarely at comfort eating; English classics like Shepherd's Pie, Lobster and chips, Oriental favourites - all served by attentive, quiet and efficient staff. The drinks bill won't knock you out and the food too is priced very competitively - especially bearing in mind they could charge what they wanted and still fill the place ten times over. My wife, probably because she's female and notices these things, is in awe of the Ladies toilets there. I wouldn't know - as I go in the other ones - but it might be worth checking out. All in all - as a package - one of the best experiences you'll get in London for under three hundred quid.

3tv8GeWv8lg9FQxz96PaPA.text: A great experience and I really enjoyed the night. The staff were also very nice and welcoming, I was happy to discover that this place is indeed amazing place to eat, beautiful, intimate and really special.Worth a try if you haven't gone there yet.

O2agyZHcrCVn4OF7GF8bzg.text: I made my booking and waited my 6 months and it was well worth it. It's actually not over-priced as you might expect, but bring enough for £60 a head, else you'll be washing some very expensive cutlery when the bill comes. The service is exquisite, our waiter was very attentive and actually smiley and not snobby at all, as I had half--expected. The staff are always keen to help, and will recommend wines and dishes for you. We had the house wine, which was only £20 a bottle, but was some of the nicest wine I've ever had and left me hangover-free the next day, which was an excellent bonus. We didn't see anyone famous, and I felt incredibly over-dressed since plenty of people were coming in in jeans. They only let you book for a two-hour slot, but we weren't hurried out when our time was up, in fact we stayed for an hour after our meal was over, enjoying the ambiance. And another bottle of house wine.

u2E3-r8K_nliW0hyigQECA.text: I love, love, LOVE this restaurant.  It is my favorite place to enjoy a nice dinner in London.  My friends and I would always go to get the foie gras. It is seriously one of the most delicious things I've ever had, and worth the visit by itself.  Another menu item I love is the coq au vin. Perfection. I haven't had anything at this place I haven't liked.  The key is to sample a few things on the menu at a time.  The portions are small, so it is a place where you can taste test.  I don't think one plate is filling enough for a whole meal, so it is definitely a starter, main dish plus kind of place. And it's a bit pricey (when I've been there, I've spent about 40 quid each time) but honestly it's worth it for a nice treat every now and then. Also located in a great part of town. Love it.

4HBeak8aMBXfUz0G7gHo_Q.text: The Ivy is a celibrity instituition known by all but what i love about it is (once you are able to get a table) it is suprisingly unpretentious. The decor is pretty and very art nouveau, with a largish dining room and understated tucked away doorway. The food is good but not exactly amazing. The menu is quite extensive and contains a mixture of different cuisines, with a fair splattering of good old English dishes throughout. The prices are not too extortionate and reflect the quality of food served. I think the Ivy is a great place to experience, but not a place to find mind blowing dishes.

u0BlfFdANnjkxd4Zg-UC4g.text: I have heard many things about The Ivy. Mostly from my Brother, who goes on about it as if it is the greatest restaurant of all time.Apparently, one of the attractions of the Ivy is that it is a magnet for celebrities. Fortunately, on the night we went, there were virtually none. In fact, the only world famous person there was me, but thankfully nobody noticed me. Nobody noticed my Father either, it seems, when the waiter accidentally punched him in the face for no reason. Yes, that really did happen, and no, I don't think he really meant it. For Starters I had Partridge, which I have been told is some kind of bird. It was delicious! Partridge on Toast, fantastic! If only I had a cheap and steady supply of Partridge at home --- it beats beans on toast any day of the week (apart from Thursdays, when beans stage a small comeback).My main course was Shepherds Pie. It was small and plain looking and I grumpily wondered, 'Is this it?' But after about three and a half bites I was full; the food was so rich! And I mean that in a good way, in a complimentary way. Although, the gravy had this weird sweet-sickly-ness to it which made it hard to finish. The atmosphere is certainly intriguing at The Ivy. Everyone sits next to eachother 'facing out', seemingly so they can see if any celebrities enter. That's what creeped me out a little, it was as if people go there just to see the famous -- whereas I think, if I want to see famous people, I'll just turn the TV on. The mild pretentiousness that the restaurant undoubtedly carries -- it's hard to tell if that's purely because of the people that eat there, or something that has been nurtured by the restaurant in aide of their reputation. I don't know. I ate there a few weeks back, for the first time, with my family; all of whom had been there before. They all said it was the worst meal they've had at The Ivy, so perhaps I caught a bad day. The thing is, though, when you go somewhere like The Ivy, which is very expensive for the average Joe, you want to be blown away, you want it to be magic.And perhaps I put my hopes too high. 'The Ivy' is okay, it's decent, it has a coolness about it but also a pretentiousness that I don't particularly love. I'd never purposefully choose to go there myself, but would be happy to go if someone invited me, especially if they were paying!

ULd9xkl7nBgzI7moU0COqw.text: The famous Ivy, amazing breakfast! I don't know what to say. Well cooked, well presented, just a party on my tongue the whole morning.

osz94V3vHei_GLoGxkyp9Q.text: Have been a few times. The food and service is excellent. You can get some good deals on the set menu, but you have to go at the right times. But it's worth it just for the experience. There is no 'pomp' here just good food in a relaxed restaurant.....you might even see a famous face.Would recommend.

CSb51kmqGvPUo2MBf2nvRQ.text: The minute you walk into The Ivy you feel like a celebrity. Food is amazing! Now I know why this place is very well known and I would definitely come back. Breakfast was simple yet elegant. I only wish I could stay for the lunch and dinner services. Great start to the day.

YX6CaAv6hxjCd8nhBHkhqg.text: I figured I shouldn't leave London without at least trying to get impressed by British cuisine, so I did some research and made a reservation at this hot spot.  Now I can say that I tried, and that I failed.The atmosphere is kind of fun, very self-consciously "scene" in a way that made me nostalgic for Los Angeles.  Photos were not allowed, no doubt to prevent me from taking pictures of the disappointing lack of Brit celebrities in the room.  Reservations were also hard to come by.  The service was good, though nothing noteworthy.The food was decent, but I think I've decided that I am incapable of getting excited over British food.  The bread was just okay, though I did find the sans-plate presentation somewhat rustic and charming if a bit awkward.  Appetizers of bang bang chicken and ruby salad were very good.  The chicken came cold with shredded vegetables all topped with hot chili peanut sauce and toasted sesame seeds and the ruby salad involved beetroots and pomegranate dressing.  Yum.  In comparison, the traditional Brit entrees felt heavy and boring.  My mother ordered the fish and chips, or deep-fried haddock with minted pea puree, chips, and tartare sauce.  I went with the steak, ale and mushroom pie.  Both tasted alright and seemed cooked according to plan, but my jaded American palate found them uninteresting.Dessert was a split.  The sticky toffee pudding with caramel sauce and vanilla ice cream was fantastic, the best bit of the meal, with deep, rich flavors tamed by the ice cream.  The blackberries with doughnuts and clotted cream ice cream, on the other hand, were very disappointing.  The little beignets were overly doughy and dense and the blackberries weak and watery.  I couldn't help but feel cheated by bad fruit in a fruit-centered dessert.The Ivy must be doing something right to maintain its status as a buzzworthy British restaurant.  Perhaps I am just immune to the charms of British vittles.  I wouldn't come back myself, but by all means, see for yourself what the fuss is all about.

zOHmqpH03Tjq9bbb54PuDw.text: Went here after the theater on a Thursday night. My friend and I wore dresses and her husband wore nice jeans and a button down shirt-- the doorman was polite but gave us the side eye. The restaurant has an old 1940s supper club vibe and most men were in jackets however we saw some guys in casualwear. As per the note on the menu, there is a no cell phone/camera policy. Anyway, the service was excellent as is expected in an upscale place like this. I ordered the spinach ravioli which was fair. My friend got the steak which was good. Her husband got the sticky toffee pudding for dessert which he loved. All in all the food was good but it didnt impress me for the price/hype.Celebrity sighting: Benji Madden from Good Charlotte

ezxCOPvIz9ssGfATByeqXQ.text: I wanted to give this place a better rating, but the initial customer service has buggered my rating. I had made reservations for my girlfriend's birthday (no longer together, the slag) but she became so ill that she required a visit to the hospital. I phoned The Ivy on the day of our reservation and explained the situation. They had my credit card information and said they had to charge me if I don't show up, and no reason seemed to matter to them. Finally, after some clever linguistic/sales skills on my part, i convinced them to let me book a reservation for the week after, but it was a headache dealing with them.So the following week the slag was better and we dined at The Ivy. The waiting staff was excellent; no problems there. However, for all the hype the food wasn't excellent, just average. I was a bit chafed I paid for an expensive meal that was only average, and that the person I had to deal with on the phone was a real ass. Oh well, we live and learn.

_c4onRaMprgywz3tTAPvkA.text: Best service I have ever experienced in London, ever.  Food was great. Atmosphere was, how should I say, upper class. Felt like a special place where the rich and famous could dine with being bugged for photos. Really tasty food and great wine.  I loved the fact while we had to wait for table they were very attentive to get us drinks, and great drinks they were.

_Ef3RI02p4_lqwu6AA0nVA.text: Probably the best meal I have ever had.  The service was sublime.  Ok, the "story" so we were in London on vacation.  I have been before, my wife and best friend had not.  We have two small children and haven't been out together in 4 years.  We hired a nanny and had a night on the town.  Before going to London I researched pubs, and found out that ribeyes are a staple at many London pubs; the best ribeye was purported to be at The Ivy.  Mistakenly I lumped The Ivy in the pub category. So we are walking around Saturday night, it's about 8pm, we're all hungry, then we see a map, it has The Ivy listed.  I say lets go there.  Fortunately we are all dressed up, Thomas Pink shirts etc.   Friend has ass length blond hair and kind of looks like a rock star.  So we power up to The Ivy, blow past the door man (remember I think this is a pub) and he says "do you have a reservation", I say "do we need one", he says "of course not".  So we go in, my miscalculation is now evident, definitely "not" a pub.   But hey, what are we going to do, turn and walk?  Hell no.  The maitre d said we could be seated in a few minutes, not bad for Saturday at 8pm, but we could only have the table for 2hrs.  Perfect.We are seated, the waiter was extraordinary.  We all got drinks, ordered a bottle of wine, steak tartare, hamachi sashimi, 2 ribeyes, and the pork sausage dish.  Oh and a bottle of very nice Kabinett.  The food was so freaking good I did not know if I should rub it on myself or eat it, I chose the later.  Service was flawless, I split hollandaise on my Thomas Pink shirt and had soda water and a towel before I knew it was there.  The bill was not any more than we would have paid at a nice restaurant in LA.  Wow, I miss this place.  What a perfect night.

TKlH8VETQ9YTPhf-G2-Pxg.text: We snuck into the Ivy on a week night without a booking. The wait staff welcomed us in and provided a well paced evening. My wife's meal was good but not memorable. My meal, a derivation of bangers 'n mash, was fantastic.Easily worth a visit.

z5797tcCRaq395PeNC5Edg.text: Good value for money and good portions of British fare. Made a reservation on a Monday night and got in easily.If you are a celeb star spotter, The Ivy is probably a 4*No photos allowed, so don't bother taking your camera.

R61dDTfweo80YP6AHfRmCA.text: You would be an asshole not to go in there, at your nearest convenience, and order the shepherd's pie with a side of green beans and the sticky toffee pudding for dessert.It's a flawless meal.Sure, they do other nice stuff.  And variety is the spice of life.  But adventure is overrated.  Unlike their ground lamb and wine reduction topped with mashed potato.  That's always spot on and its praises cannot be sung loudly enough.

DUYECovkQ29ZwYuDXqC9qA.text: This joint is my claim to fame! Upon walking in here i was drowned in stars! Standing next to Lemar at the bar, Nelson Mandela was a couple tables infront, Borris Johnson was in the building and so was some other familiar faces. Not expensive, real English food, great service but its strictly a 'not what you know but who you know' place ie. if youve got £££ and your prepared to give the waiter a pink one then you can be seated straight away (like Lemar) or you can book like a mortal unless your in with the management staff, then your ballin!Food wise, dont expect anything special, your essentially coming to a pub.No cameras allowed!

PtHhgk8X7OQI0E-74WsHOA.text: Visited The Ivy for my third wedding anniversary. It was a Tuesday evening but by 8pm there was a nice buzz in the restaurant, not overly loud, just pleasant I thought.  Had a really delicious starter of seared squid salad (£11), followed by a pleasant main of lamb (£26).  The side order of chips were really disappointing - they were limp fries, like you would discover at the bottom of a McDonalds bag.  Shared a dessert of pistachio chocolate doughnuts which weren't great value at £8 (4 doughnuts, a few crushed pistachios and a dribble of chocolate sauce).  The bill for 2 starters, 2 mains, a dessert and 2 cocktails came to £130 (including 12.5% service charge and also £8 worth of "cover charges").  Overall it's a pretty pleasant place to eat, some of the food is tasty (but not fine dining), and I don't think I would have been entirely delighted with paying £130 had I not been using a £100 voucher.

wVw20KpEJSL6NZFS-3AvaA.text: Coming back into The Ivy, stationed on Covent Garden's West Street for the last 90 years, is like sliding into a favourite chair, or pulling on 'that' pair of jeans. It's somewhere that makes you feel comfortable and cosseted. Whether you're going there weekly, or for your first visit, once you're on the other side of the stained glass panelled windows, you're treated like you belong.The sense of history at the restaurant comes more from the staff than the decor. It's not a formula, they're all allowed to express their own personalities and behave like, well, human beings. Compared to some of the Michelin starred restaurants in town, with their robotic teams of perfectly drilled matched staff, that's got to be a positive. They keep their staff, and move them round within the Caprice Holdings Group (for of course it is they, along with Sheekeys, Scotts, Caprice and newer sibling the Dean Street Townhouse) and there are enough people on their board of directors who have been with the business for 20 years or more who worked their way up. Jesus Adorno (with Le Caprice since the day it opened in 1981), Fernando Piero (the formidably cultured director of The Ivy) and chief exec Des MacDonald are, for some, better known than most restauranteurs.I used to be brought in here by suppliers and clients, when I worked more regularly in the theatre, and you could always spot those who didn't go there often. They would call you up with a time and date, clutched like a golden ticket, their voices quavering with excitement, two months out. The Ivy doesn't work like that. Like most top restaurants, they dress the room keeping back tables for nearer the time, to ensure that the right mix of people fill the space (a balance of industry, entertainment, old friends and the odd rubbernecker). It's more casual than many think, shhhh... they now take some (non peak) bookings online...Warning signs should flash here. It's NOT somewhere for a special meal. It's a good, rising to great, local restaurant. So often do you see or hear people comparing unfavourably to Le Gavroche or Royal Hospital Road, but truth be told, it's not trying to compete. The food focusses on simple ingredients, cooked well, British cuisine with some (very loose) Med influences and a strong focus on matching seasonality with their old favourites. Yes they have a pasta list, but you could sample their expertly made gnocchi following a starter of caviar or tuna sashimi. The winelist is extensive, intelligent and full of enough surprises at all levels. A standout Douro and an aromatic Gavi di Gavi are highlights on a small list by the glass.I go for a spicily perfect Steak Tartare that comes with fresh toast (seemlessly replaced when I run out), my guest's Beetroot and Goat's cheese salad comes studded with tiny blue edible flowers and a rapeseed oil dressing. I enschew the usual shepherd's pie (one of their more famed dishes, rightly so, along with an excellent burger and a surprisingly good, though inauthentic curry - see what I mean about it being simple food here?) and go for a meaty and thick monkfish tail (one of several daily, seasonal specials) served with saltily spiky coastal greens and a butter sauce. My guest had a Blythbourne Pork Belly with lentils, morcilla and peas. Sated, we skipped dessert, though I could recommend a slate of frozen Scandinavian Berries with a hot white chocolate sauce, another regular on a groaning dessert list. We take coffee and try to recover.

DnC-PfcuIv5ARdJpqP6Zsw.text: The Ivy is a restaurant that lends itself to lofty expectations--from the neighborhood to the reactions of the people who were very impressed that I was to be dining at The Ivy to the amazing service and food.  However legendary the experience is meant to be however--and I did find it both delicious and pleasant--it is ultimately not one of those experiences you'll remember forever the way its built up to be.When I told anyone that asked about my party's dinner reservation at the Ivy, they were quite impressed, so my expectations were soaring.  We arrived before the remainder of our party, so we went to the bar.  Right off the bat I wasn't impressed as the bar was small and the "bar area" was even smaller.  The drink list however was extensive, so not to worry.Once seated, I couldn't exactly get past how cramped the whole place was, but this was a common thread at all the places I'd eaten this trip.  The service--if you can believe it--actually seemed to thrive in this atmosphere, moving the table to allow you to sit (instead of pulling your chair out for you).Can't say enough about the service, which is beyond top notch in every imagineable way, from the serving of the food to the presenting of the menu, which brings me to the food itself.  To be completely honest, I was disappointed with the menu, expecting more fancy options, and just more options in general.  I was extremely happy with my choices however.  I had a gnocci appetiser which was (no exaggeration) the best gnocci I've ever had in my entire life.  My main course was a deliciously tender and juicy porkbelly.  With help from the large table, we sampled an array of the available desserts all of which were fantastic.All in all, this was a really really top notch meal, complete with three courses and fantastic service.  HOWEVER, if you find yourself in London with your heart set on eating at The Ivy and for some reason you can't get a reservation or a table, there's no question in mind that you can get something comporable at a different high end restaurant in the area or out of it.

Hppdi-SO4Ya_EuNZ4v3k8A.text: What else can I say about the Ivy. Either downstairs at the restaurant or upstairs at the club bar or restaurant, the service is impeccable and the food delicious. I am addicted to the dover sole with butter and the Twinkle cocktail.

-vrumJsNyqhunsBQraqGZQ.text: I've been here a couple of times and I can say the place is quite nice  comfortable atmosphere with appropriate distance between the tables. However, if the place is too packed you may have to wait a while for your order.

fEwDcfr1vh-56iNUoQM2cw.text: One of two great restaurants we've eaten at in our neighbourhood, which is the Covent Garden area, The Ivy is supposed to be a high-profile-celebs-eatery/hangout. Well, I wouldn't know about that, since we've only eaten there twice and both times downstairs, not up in the dark-secret-sshhh-you-don't-know-I'm-here-room. The Ivy has food that is actually perfectly prepared from scratch from fresh ingredients. I know. Amazing concept, eh? Too bad very few other restaurants in London have figured out this simple approach. Yes, it can be hard to get a last-minute table, unless you are willing to eat early or very late. The first time we booked several weeks in advance for a Sunday night with relatives, the second time we only gave them a few days' notice and both times we were able to be accommodated within an hour of our preferred time, which was fine.Our first dinner was not as spectacular as the second, but that's because the first time our guests were paying (not us) so I had a less-expensive option. The second time I took a chance and ordered the lobster, which I've eaten all over the world, including famous lobster joints in New York City, to greater or lesser success. Some of the fanciest lobster restaurants serve you an animal that is overcooked and rubbery, and some of the simplest ones have given the best result. Before this night, my most memorable lobster was eaten in a small, inexpensive family restaurant in Roundstone, Connemara, Ireland. Perfect, simple, tender, delicious. Was caught in the bay right in front of the restaurant and steamed and served with a simple butter/parsley sauce that wasn't even necessary, the lobster was so good. Until my meal at The Ivy I had pretty much decided that unless I went back to Galway, I would never taste lobster that good again. But it was perfect, just as fresh and just as delicious and simply prepared. I didn't need the little bowl of fresh-cut and fried chips (but needless to say, I ate them anyway, The Ivy's chips are great!) because the lobster on its own was so good. Difference in price? Considerable. The Roundstone lobster with a full compliment of sides, fresh veg and chips, was 19 Irish Punts (in 1996). The Ivy lobster was something like £35 and the chips and salad were extra. But definitely worth it for a special treat, and when you've gotten oh, so tired of being served horrible food from the rest of the places in London.My husband had fish and chips and mushy peas, made from fresh-caught fish and fresh new minted peas, and pronounced it the best F&C he'd ever eaten. Our guests had steak and ditto. No one had a bad meal there and we were only sorry we were too full after licking our plates clean to indulge in some of the obviously amazing-looking desserts the next table over were sharing to great acclaim and gusto.We were treated as though we were important and special (which, of course we are! Only they couldn't know that....) and as valued a set of customers as Madonna and Sting upstairs. Or whoever it was that night in the hush-hush room.We will definitely eat at The Ivy again when we return to our London home from Canada. I keep having dreams about that lobster....

h-qwpdw993IEDwHRU-gGrw.text: So let me start of by saying "I don't typically dine at restaurants like this." Luckily for me, my boyfriend's best mate made reservations and even paid for the whole thing! We ordered the mixed seafood platter, which was AMAZING! The scallops were perfectly cooked and the presentation was exquisite. If you order this dish, be prepared to get messy and sit in a position with plenty of elbow room --- you'll need it!The shellfish bisque was also one of my favorite starters! Loved it! I wished I would have ordered the Shepard's Pie, what was I thinking? I've never had Shepard's pie before but hear it's great traditional English comfort food.The ambiance is exactly like their website, same color palette and has a very simple, yet elegant feel. It's decor is the opposite of what you'd expect from Nobu, but you already knew that...As you may know from my previous reviews, I'm HUGE on customer service. The entire staff was friendly and helpful as expected. If it were any different, you bet I would tell you about it here :)

FX8mXWs6Hrl9kE3ENj4RcA.text: I was lucky enough to get a table, after 4 months waiting!! So I was of course expecting the best!!! Food is average. Service is good. Atmosphere is pretty desperate! Overall I wouldn't go back or recommend it to a friend, there are many more places in London.

CSV92bu1tGskSkrTwxPWoQ.text: One of the finest resturants I have been to. The staff were very friendly, I would recommend this resturant.

Yk-Ynm1wsXFz1C2rukaf9A.text: Myself and two other girlfriends came down to London from Stirling in Scotland for a birthday weekend. We went to the Ivy for lunch and were not disappointed. The Shepherds Pie was to die for, rich and filling and the Custard on the Apple Pie was just heavenly.The atmosphere was nice, no music but lots of chatter as the place was full,(unfortunately no celebs in that day!). Toilets slightly below expectations but the service was good, and overall not too expensive.

CB69qsdJWWkSjDaGTSHB2A.text: The food and atmosphere is excellent at The Ivy. I had my first Baked Alaska there and the presentation was just as amazing as the dessert itself. I'm back there again today!!

K6q86ubSYSYPJ5xvYwwy3A.text: First i must say that the last time i visited The Ivy was about 3 years ago. That said the food was tasty, i had a steak for my main, and atmosphere was nice. Staff were helpful too but i couldnt help feel that i was paying a premium for the food simply due to the reputation as a celeb hang out. Though there weren't any when we were there :-(

JkPo4gnj4k_-sbNgTxvCEA.text: We turned up without a booking on Friday evening after a short theatre performance and were greeted in a friendly way and given a table for an hour. Deciding not to have starters, I opted for the cod and my friend for the calves liver, both on the recommendation of a friendly Portuguese waiter. My fish was fresh tasting, in a subtle creamy sauce and had an excellent texture. The calves liver was very good too. We also enjoyed our desserts of cheesecake and apple pie - the latter my friend declared was the 'best ever'. We didn't recognise any celebs though.

SqCW6FoqDfXv7km7kmAnvg.text: Their diary for bookings is only open up to 3 months in advance (if you're not a celeb anyway!), so I had to phone EVERY day for about 6 weeks waiting for the dates to be opened for my planned visit to London. Within hours though, the evening slots were fuly booked, for 3 months in advance, but we were offered a lunchtime slot instead, which we took. It was an experience, very bubbly and lively atmosphere but also very relaxed - perfect for a ladies lunch. The food was amazing good old fashioned homecooked choices but very nice indeed and the icing on the cake was sitting next to Natalie Appleton - who commented that she like my bracelet!!! A perfect Friday afternoon, relaxing, eating and chatting over a few glasses of wine - well worth a visit if you can get in!!!!

QOvNMjMNYLVWnXOCTRhShA.text: I had lunch at the club at the ivy. I have to say I was very impressed. The decor has been beautiful done. They have continued the art nouveau theme of the main restaurant upstairs. The food was also to the same high standard, as was the service.

rtK4jHZFmjjgw-YHgbh8EQ.text: Had an excellent roast dinner here and dabbled in some satr spotting (a certain member of Blue was sat on the next table with some groupies). Service is great and the staff are friendly and knowledgable.

Zr-a5hTWefNqapdSfpJBNA.text: i visited the ivy about two years ago (2006) and have to say it was one of my favourtie dining experiences ever! cheaper and less pretentious than Boxwood and slightly more relaxed and cutting edge than the savoy, everything from the atmosphere and service to the food was excellent, hence why i can still remember it two years on! As previously stated in other reviews, it is not cheap, but is definitely value for money and is not as expensive as some may think.

nUDqcWeW6ve05rCCW-gcIA.text: Food was okay - small portions though. Great for an important birthday. Spoke to john cleese and princess ann when i was there a few years back.

U-vBKNWGQC5RporK0kSsvQ.text: I loved The Ivy. I agree that there are better restaurants in London, but if you've heard of it and are curious to give it a try, I'd heartily recommend it. Very unpretentious, good value British classic dishes and impeccable service. Oh, we 'got' Debbie Harry when we visited!

wSK0_k8zzCChKraWgHyyNw.text: Good traditional British food. I normally take friends as a birthday treat. They used to have a weekend 3 course set menu that was under £27. The prices generally are not that expensive. The beef on a Sunday is particulary tasty and filling,served with roast potatoes and yorkshire pudding - yummy. Waiters are attentive and friendly.

pAmlepTLpT4H9zy_cssmSg.text: Let's face it, this one is about people watchingit is pricey and the food is not always up to scratch (for the size of the bill) but it is still a fun place for business lunch or dinner. Seafood is good, and their Dover sole hits the spot every time.

y9993L6ZYlC58WO8BsNZAw.text: This resturant was ok - not as posh as i thought it would be given all the hype!Four of us had to book 6months to the day in advance which was pretty annoying! Then they only had a table available at 10.30pm but obviously didnt want to have to wait another 6months to make sure that we got this date (it was a birthday) so just had to go late.The food was ok, but nothing to really wow you! But then this could be a plus side as the menu had favourite classics like shepards pie and burger and chips! If you wanted to go spending a fourtune and breaking the bank you could - if you wanted to take it easily, then this was possible all so. We only really went as we have heard how exculsive this place was and wanted to see what all the fuss was about really! We saw one of the girls from girls alloud in there and that horse racing bloke John Mcriccick? So i guess it really is the place where the celebs hang out!All in all, i thought it was a lovely experience and i am glad that we went. Probably would do it again though as i have done this now and there are plenty of other resturants with waiting lists!

_VIbXl6DxB26fTQw6YUBpw.text: was curious to see what all the fuss was about, and was nicely surpriced at the laid back and friendly surroundings. if i.m honest in terms of food although good there are better resturants around but still a good night out

TCLAX0vlm3NOQfhbAEgKmg.text: really nice place to eat, great service, great food.

D5Nf8ZWf_J32zhGDWowHfw.text: I went here for pre-show dining with some friends and we had a great time. The service here is good although the atmosphere was not what I expected. I had heard that The Ivy was a celebrity magnet, but mostly I saw lots of quiet, wealthy, older people dining here. Strangely enough, everyone in there was wearing black too. It was a quieter atmosphere than I'd expected.The food was good (not amazing but decent), my friends were loving the foie gras especially. I would have expected such a place to be really expensive, but it was reasonable considering.

lpVLKBoOFsApQXybLFVwQA.text: My favourite restaurant in London.I believe that this is the most perfect restaurant I have ever encountered. It's beautiful, serves lovely food at very reasonable prices and the service is exquisite. I often meet a friend here and I'm the one that gets to places early. The staff always make me feel at home; they don't mind if you sit at the table alone and will usually bring a newspaper (The Times) to keep you occupied while you wait.The food is fabulous. I almost always have the fish of the day, but have tried most of the menu. Their burger, shepherd's pie and the corned beef hash are pure comfort food. I don't often bother with dessert, but if there are enough of us, it's always fun to get the baked alaska to have it set on fire next to the table. It's just the most lovely, relaxed, quietly perfect place!

ZNAZIteHZOqHe7kY4Ed_mg.text: Great ambiance, excellent and attentive service, varied menu and terrific wine selection make this restaurant in a very popular area of London a go to top choice. Dining here felt a little like I was dining with the who's who of the West End. I ordered the salmon and was pleasantly surprised with the taste, quality and presentation. I will return next time I'm in the UK.

xzlrW80GWaqUbXqup04f-A.text: Upon arrival the hostess said there were no tables available on the patio, yet two sat empty and dressed. Furthermore, she said there were no reservations for outdoor seating and told me to try coming back in 30 minutes. My husband and I sat outside on a bench and waited for a bit, watched the terrace from afar, and approximately 15 min later, the restaurant sat someone at one of the vacant tables on the patio. The waitress was rude on both occasions. It's too bad as the cafe seemed quite cute and the cuisine looked delicious. I will not return!

3J4VlQktle6usob0DfkqlA.text: Most attentive and understanding wait staff, we are SO appreciative!Long story short, someone bought us a bottle of champagne and became a bit too obnoxious.. The waitstaff was incredible. They got us to the bathroom, snuck our bags up to us from our table, and shuffled us out the private exit. Not only a great waitstaff, but AMAZING food and a great environment. I got a fish and shrimp dish, my cousin got the salmon, we split a cheese plate and the clementine sponge cake for dessert.Special thanks to our waiter (can't remember his name, but he's from Southern italy) who was incredible, as well as the assistant manager. Both were so understanding and very intuitive. Will definitely visit again the next time I'm in England, had a great time! Except why wasn't one direction there? (;

beBQm5Fpj3RVC3l8q8u01w.text: This is an unapologetic old school restaurant with excellent service and really good food.   I wouldn't call it inventive and it's not cheap but from what I can see you are assured of a nice night out when you go there.   The desserts were definitely a high point so save room!

R_gIjXrV2T7CM9wfzmY6Tw.text: I am a notorious - gotta try the hot restaurants at least once kinda girl.  I've heard about the Ivy (the one in LA is def a bigger hype) but was a little disappointed at the type of food it was offering.  Let's talk about the good - The ambiance is nice as well as the service... but like the other reviews it isn't fine dining.  Lots of variety so it's good to go in a group who need it.  Not so good - Sorry to say it's the food.  I had the spinach ravioli to start... a bit underwhelmed.  The shepherd's pie everyone is raving about... I thought it was a little too salty and actually didn't feel too good after the meal.  Sadly, I think you'd get better food at a nice gastro pub (like the prince of wales in putney).  I don't see myself coming back here again.

EDHmv8afaIaI-iRNdJivSQ.text: Went here in celebration of my husband's birthday during our trip to London, and we were really excited to be able to get a reservation despite short notice (booked a day in advance, though it was for a fairly early dinner time). If I were just rating the food, and if not for a couple of incidents, I would probably have given this place four stars. The food was well prepared and satisfying, in particular the corn bisque. My chicken breast entree was quite juicy, and i would recommend the sorbet and fruit dessert (very fresh).The service, however, was mediocre at best. Our waitress expected us to order food almost immediately upon sitting down, before we had even ordered drinks. Our appetizers came out fairly promptly, but our entrees were very slow to arrive. The most shocking service offense happened at the very end of the meal. My husband and I had clearly finished out dessert and tea and had gotten well beyond the point where we were ready to go, but our waitress was no where to be found. We probably sat there for a good 20-30 mins, when one of the hosts came over and told us they needed the table for other diners. Why in the world he would not have first told our waitress to bring the check, or even brought it himself, is beyond us. I thought this was a pretty unacceptable ending to what otherwise would have been a pleasant evening overall.To the staff at The Ivy: if you need your guests to be done, bring the check. It's that simple.

QcztNgjrUmFQ7DiaISBOcw.text: Little jewel in London. Great food , beautiful space and great ambiance. Elegant setting paired with a sophisticated menu and fantastic wine list. The restaurant group behind it owns several restaurants that I've tried -- while they are all very good, the Ivy is the crown jewel.

R8nuS3hQDJtvDTF3tBpHdg.text: Wow - great food, great service.  A number of the dishes were very inspired and everything we had was executed to perfection.And not overly pricy considering location and quality.

2rE2pgLnA6_aN9HIy9uM4w.text: I love The Ivy, we come here a lot. We always have the Baked Alaska- the theatre of the dish is great. They set it alight and then serve it. It's like a mini show at your table. A great way to get noticed! They could probably invest a little more time into their vegetarian menu though.

sjfX8VeinI0VJmgXY4dmBg.text: I've only been to the Ivy three times with my work friends.And I'm going back 2005 to 2007, not much has changed at the Ivy.The Ivy is the one of the best places for me to do some paparazzi work,(i.e. celebrity spotting).

riKVl055AZHtJmk2P65yhQ.text: The restaurant is laid out to create good buzz and ambiance. Menu selection broad and food quality is excellent as well as the service. Service is attentive but no over bearing.I had the grilled foie gras to start and crab crusted cod for the main. Both right size portions, clean presentation and very good.Location is great and when your down your in the middle of central London.

slQDcGa3TlBCgAtku8-E4w.text: Apparently this is a members bar? Odd.... I got in! Lol but I was invited.... I didn't break in via the back door. It was lovely, I mean the glass lift started things off nicely, I felt like Charlie in the glass elevator! .... Wait it was Charlie right? Either way the drinks were quality, the food was delicious. I'd go again.

t1L8zz0SmMj8VSeI6h-MSg.text: We went here invited by a friend, and were clearly not disappointed.First of all the place itself is very nice. Cosy, big but well planned meaning one has no impression of being in a huge restaurant, on the contrary.The food is simply excellent. Don't go here if you want the experimental cuisine, but go here if you want classic dishes made to perfection. A sirloin steak cooked just as needed, little spices, just excellent. And steak tartare prepared as it should be. According to comments around our table, the other dishes such as fish are excellent too. We did not test the starters though. Then desserts... they have a chocolate fondant which is probably the best I've ever had, if not the best. The creme brulee was very good too (not in the same league as the chocolate fondant though ;-) )As for the service: perfect service. Always a smile, efficient, showing you interest in what they're doing. So go there for an excellent dinner, with a classic touch, and perfect service.And better book, apparently it's nightmare to get a table.

tBDPFP9TPYgmrPGNkKKjpg.text: The Beatles ate here.  Well, probably everyone else did too, since this place has been around forever.  The look of the place reminded me a little of The Palm restaurants in America.  Old wood, linen table cloths, superb service, etc.The food is good but not great, but it's a very comfortable place to have a quiet meal, and it's central to everything.

KU1tKiHpbwKQmr9pSQdVhw.text: After reading a review and getting a recommendation to dine at The Ivy we finally did and enjoyed it quite a bit. We went for lunch and tried the set menu of 3 courses. I started with the feta, watermelon and mint salad which is a personal favorite. The salad was fantastic and beautifully presented as you might imagine. The main course I tried was the Sea Bass and again I was not disappointed in the presentation, preparation or flavor. Their wine selection is nice and included a torrontes wine which we enjoyed very much. For the grand finish I had the Strawberry Royal and would recommend any of the above items. During my university years I served at a country club so I especially appreciated the servers working gracefully presenting the plate with "The Ivy" at the 12 o'clock position each time. These guys were smooth at resetting and attending each guest. It's the little things that make a guest experience. The furnishings are in good shape and the stained glass windows that surround the dining room are quite beautiful in the light. I found the dining room warm, intimate and it did not feel old and stodgy like I had feared it might. The clientele seemed to be a good mix of ages. I was a bit concerned about attire since one persons had written they had dined in a suit and in trainers. (hopefully not in one ensemble) LOL! Most people were dressed well and I didn't spot any trainers, even on the nearby children. This American Southerner believes eating at The Ivy won't just grow on you but leave you anticipating your next fine dining experience with them. Bon appetite, y'all!

photos.caption: Photo of The Ivy - London, United Kingdom. Strawberry Royal dessert
Photo of The Ivy - London, United Kingdom. Place setting

5lkCCaz2DhoErkWTi4dQNQ.text: Summary: Great location and ambiance, food was just ok and expensiveCame here after reading a recommendation from the chef of St. John. Tried the shepherd's pie, based on the waiter's recommendation, and cheese cauliflower. The food was fairly expensive for what it was. Tasted decent, not great.Wouldn't come back.

KKimYKLTq1QKdMUuQzCrnA.text: We ate there on a Tuesday night and thought it was terrific.The table service was exceptional, especially since we found that we had to rush dinner to catch our show.Seafood bisque: excellent.

WtUPO7Y48F0xqOF95kJfpw.text: Had a lovely mid- week dinner at the Ivy. Great ambience, food was excellent, staff were very attentive.

VElOEQZFrZzHoxVnphGvcA.text: Came here for dinner.  Started with the burrata salad, gnocchi and squid salad. The squid salad was tender and flavourful. The burrata and gnocchi were good.  Between the 4 of us we had the ribeye, the fillet, the sea bass and the sausage. The ribeye was juicy and flavourful.  They served English, Dijon and seed mustard.  This was definitely a great compliment to the steaks!!!  We had the lemon ricotta tart, the window to the ivy and a hot fudge Sunday.  The window to the ivy was the 100 year anniversary dessert. It was very rich with drunk cherries.  Great place to eat!  I recommend this place!
