psgiqnwkytHR2A_sEWLWkw.text: EN: I really loved this restaurant. The décor and the food were perfect. I ordered the spicy masman chicken curry but asked them to go easy on the spicy part and the flavour was just right. Service was impeccable, as well. SP: Me encanto este restaurante. La decoración y la comida estaban increíbles. Pedí el curry masman de pollo pero les pedí que no lo hicieran tan picante y estaba buenísimo. El mesero súper buena onda también.

photos.caption: Photo of The Ivy - London, United Kingdom

3GN6M6Dde1XZ2ZUvK3w0vQ.text: Walking around Covent Garden in the morning, I stumbled on The Ivy and it was open at 8am. I didn't expect much from the food, especially after hearing that London has subpar food, but The Ivy surprised me. Service was courteous and attentive.  And the decor was beautiful with fantastic natural lightning. I enjoyed both the Eggs Benedict and Vegetarian Breakfast, and enjoyed having eggs were perfectly poached.

photos.caption: Photo of The Ivy - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Ivy - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Ivy - London, United Kingdom

1IUjL-9NhNQg0fsiMcAILQ.text: Great location. Drinks on the pricey side for what you get. Delicious olives appetizer. FIsh and Chips were tasty. Good, attentive service.

3vEKGczAWwUDr73yx3R7MA.text: Very classy very pricey very small portions and every thing is listed as a side dish! When you order meat for 23 pounds , literally only the meat slice comes on a white plate. Nothing next to it. Not even sauce. Greens, potatoes, everything every thing is priced seperately. BUT great coctails and wine. So it is more like a light bite and a drink kind of a restaurant or maybe for special occasions

Q2pAIKz98ilwOnzXDq9KUg.text: Super classy restaurant, very European, beautiful decor, superb food & drinks, implacable service (thank you, Darren!), vegan & vegetarian friendly.Husband and I made reservations for late night dinner at the bar. And what a bar it is! Located in the middle of the restaurant, allowing you to enjoy both a very intimate dinner sitting next to each other and a wonderful view of the restaurant. If you wish to make dinner reservations for a couple, I would definitely recommend sitting at the bar. Our lovely bartender, Darren, went over the (vegetarian!) menu with us and gave us advice as to which of the dishes could be veganized. He even consulted with the chef. Everything we ordered was sublime, so was our entire evening.

TnIhFLnexRIkCEJdxm78nQ.text: Great food & service from The Ivy, London! The table was set beautifully and the attention to detail was excellent, and staff are all so friendly.I ate from the Set Menu which changes regularly and is served Monday-Thursday 2.30pm -6pm & after 10pm also Sunday's all day.Starter - Bruschetta with stuffed olives, piquillo, avocado & Ortiz anchovies - The Bruschetta had just the right amount of softness to crunch and tasted sublime! I'm not a fan of anchovies but these were Ortiz anchovies so I had to try them which I did, but still didn't approve! But the starter was great and again the presentation was excellent! I highly applaud the chefs and kitchen staff for their presentation.Main - Rosemary lamb burger with sweet aubergine relish & sumac yoghurt - The lamb was out of this world! You know when the meat falls apart, its been cooked to perfection and WOW the sweet aubergine relish & sumac yoghurt was out of this world! And obviously I had to have a side of chips which were equally as tasty!Dessert - Chocolate fudge sundae - I am a big chocolate fudge sundae fan and this was without a shadow of doubt the best sundae I have ever had! I can't even explain the taste as its making me drawl thinking about it. You're going to have to visit The Ivy, have a sundae and let me know what you think!If you're looking for a real treat, possibly for a birthday or anniversary then book a table at The Ivy as your be wined and dined the right way. Plus take advantage of the Set Menu's and Pre Theatre Menu's which are available.

3l7nIrInwqPFaggRaVrJtg.text: Everything from the wine to the appetizers to the filet was... fine. We didn't feel like it was spectacular enough to justify the prices. Overall just an average meal, however, the service was excellent.

cuEFWDdBC988FWUwt1swmg.text: Absolutely loved every minute of it!The location is perfect, close to the lively West End of London.  The building is period with all the features to go with it, even stained glass!  As the doorman open the door you are transported to the 60's!  They have one of the most beautiful bars I've ever seen!  Dressed in dirty pink with stunning barman waiting to serve you.  Every cocktail on the menu is fresh and original served in a special way reminding you of the 60's...Once transported to your table we we presented with wonderful plates of food.  Well prepared and beautifully presented!  During the visit the gorgeous waiters looked after our every need without being overbearing.

photos.caption: Photo of The Ivy - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Ivy - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Ivy - London, United Kingdom

zxbgwuL9UiL6_T-lbvfQiQ.text: I'm in love. I was in love with Sheekey, which don't get me wrong is still my favorite restaurant in the world, but The Ivy is right up there. We made reservations on a very rainy January night and arrived an hour early...we sat at the bar and had some drinks, enjoyed talking with everyone at the bar and tried some fantastic wine. When our table was finally ready, we started with the smoked salmon with horseradish cream.  I have yet to have bad smoked salmon in London, but the horseradish cream was a nice switch up. For my main I had the pork sausages with colcannon and cider gravy...best sausages ever! I'm a cider person and I wouldn't be opposed to bathing in that cider gravy. It was phenomenal.  My mother and I tried two desserts, both were excellent (unsurprisingly) but the thing I loved most was the espresso martini. I am not a martini person. Like never...But after seeing people order it at the bar, I had to try it! It was DELICIOUS.  Next time I will order it sooner, hell probably have a couple. I can't wait to return. Ivy has been added to my rotation (and I live in California, so that's saying something)!

uXGpW9WvL-kmcFixa8gx4g.text: A beautiful dining experience.All day on Mondays they have a set 2 or 3 course menu, so we went along to celebrate a friends engagement as a special treat.The setting is very classic, dim lighting, lovely tables, gorgeous stained glass windows.The staff were all brilliant, helpful and very kind.Three courses for £27 in such an institution of place was great value.We had a delicious bottle of sav blanc, which for £29 wasn't too bad at all, considering where we were.The Resturant was constantly busy, creating a fab atmosphere, but the staff were always attentive. We finished off our meal with after dinner cocktails, which were delicious.They let us have our table for over an hour longer than we were supposed to, before politely moving us to the bar.Overall a fantastic evening. I'd highly recommend taking advantage of the seasonal set menu and treating yourself to an Ivy experience.

photos.caption: Photo of The Ivy - London, United Kingdom. Finishing off the evening with an espresso martini
Photo of The Ivy - London, United Kingdom. Our array of desserts - blue cheese and blackcurrant jam, rice pudding and chocolate and honeycomb. Delicious.
Photo of The Ivy - London, United Kingdom. Beautifully cooked salmon

AR5nKkqj3Rs-qfwe0fa2SA.text: Right next to covent garden. No wait for a table for two !!!! The food was prepared in 30 minutes. Amazing sirloin steak with delicious peppercorn sauce. Would definitely come back next time in London

Ol1N7FWbMw2NAqucx4J8XA.text: After recently being refurbished, I thought I would give this place a go.I arrived for lunch without a reservation and was warmly welcomed and asked to sit at the bar. The bar staff were great and happily made up a very moorish virgin cocktail. Unfortunately I can't remember the name.I went classic and had sausage and mash. Truly amazing. Perfect gravy and a surprisingly healthy size portion based on a restaurant of this standard.Highly recommend a visit for those classic dishes, with a high level of service to make it feel extra special. (Visit - 28/07/2015)

CPAzzVfQKiqj9Lv2SLzQFQ.text: This place is legendary. The food quality has decreased in recent years, but the crowd and the place is hard to beat. For a piece of vintage london, definitely visit.

I0bCqOIQ_P_4Yvgppr27ug.text: Following the refurb, The Ivy is better than ever. The menu has lost its grounded charm but doesn't fail otherwise. Staff are mostly gorgeous and chic, kitted out in uniforms they would surely choose for themselves; and you never fail to spot a 'face', lunch or dinner.

photos.caption: Photo of The Ivy - London, United Kingdom. Carved marble deco tiles in the ladies room - a contender for classiest loos?
Photo of The Ivy - London, United Kingdom. Deco lighting and interiors makes The Ivy one of the most stylish restaurants in London

UV10QcKRT0h9O72q8nxcgw.text: The great ambience and drink menu. The staff was excellent and extremely knowledgeable. The food was very good as well. We ate at the bar and I would highly recommend it. Very cool place to have a dinner.

BZR6KNoiHec32FkcW-CuLw.text: Average food in an average decor. A sort of in- set, cosy crowd. What's the fuss? Celebrities? The coat check as you enter? The Majordomo at the door as you leave? I was with a well-known person who was treated with a warm welcome and British deferencen he made the rounds of the tables greeting acquaintances like old friends- so I guess that's the deal? Be seen, try it out for the attitude not the food. The 21 Club NYC has it over this....

htuq75iFFuXcUXrQTU3pvA.text: Excellent pre fixe menu. Gorgeous art deco dining room. Will definitely be back on my next visit to London.

aVZlsDnNb3edY-l6D2q1UA.text: Enjoyed an after the "theater show" dinner while visiting London.  Service was prompt and courteous, and we enjoyed the dinner.

4vU6BHM1JjMvLrF0eEDbng.text: Fantastic cheeky place with fantastic food and service and atmosphere galore. It felt as though I was on a movie set from the 1920's - I will be back again when I visit from America.

xLPRwpdufvCyz8NiWKQSDA.text: Came on a Saturday night alone as I was traveling for work. LOVE love sitting at this bar! The friendliest bartenders, the cutest pink velour bar seats with marble countertops make this an adorable bar setup - not to mention glasses that look like Waterford crystal and stained glass windows! Just picture perfect.I ordered the watermelon duck summer salad which was incredible - the perfect amount of spicy, sweet and refreshing. Never heard of a dish like this. I also had the seafood pasta for dinner which was yummy but nothing to write home about. I will 100000% be back as a solo diner.

photos.caption: Photo of The Ivy - London, United Kingdom

0WH5P5KrmYsCW5KgOuTUHg.text: This place is AMAZING!! the food, the atmosphere, the decor, the starters, the drinks, the hostess. Everything was absolutely amazing and reasonably priced, cannot wait to come back here on my next trip to London!

VYVcuWQcsMTvmGh_cjUb0A.text: Having started off as a modest café in 1917, The Ivy has such a storied history. Since then, it has grown into one of London's most quintessential restaurants. You can't possibly go wrong ordering British staples here, such as their famous shepherd's pie. Just be sure not to fill yourself up too much on the complimentary bread to start. After all, it's a good idea to save room for (at least) one of their dessert puddings.

photos.caption: Photo of The Ivy - London, United Kingdom. Masman Tiger Prawn Curry (25)
Photo of The Ivy - London, United Kingdom. The Ivy Shepherds Pie (19.50)

bcgR6Z1kAHN7mRlfBfHo8w.text: Sometimes restaurants in theater districts can be a little disappointing -- average food & service, priced high. This is definitely not the case with the long-standing Ivy. Everything was perfect -- the ambiance, food and service put smiles on the faces of every member of our tribe. We met a lovely couple at the adjoining table having a night out without the kids, and they seemed just as pleased.

lSzqClJ68MAgH8Ifad-VuQ.text: Last night in London and I had not had shepards pie so I did some searches on my phone and everyone came back with The Ivy as the best around. It was by far the best I have ever had. If I could get an IV of the sauce at the bottom of the bowl I would be a happy man. All the food was very good, the wine list was varied but a bit pricey. Over all a must visit when in London

9p-SayC54Yxl4dN9GaOgVQ.text: My first time at The Ivy and wow was it amazing. The food was delicious. I had the bang bang chicken for starter and a corn fed chicken for the main. I enjoyed a class of full body Nappa Valley wine. Service was very attentive, the lady from Portugal was lovely, she smiled, hosted and engaged with the customers. The atmosphere was laid back, opulent and comfortable. People dressed casual smart and there was no arrogance from any of staff. They were extremely friendly. In all I had an amazing experience, delicious food, good wine and friendly service. Would definitely return.

photos.caption: Photo of The Ivy - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Ivy - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Ivy - London, United Kingdom

sRLrSbsz8ESFviU8d0IauA.text: Wow! Just a proper lovely place with amazing food. Very english posh, great service but most importantly the food! Very hard to get in for dinner but same menu is available for lunch. I did not go for drinks but i would recommend start with a cocktail and then get something from their infamous wine list.

photos.caption: Photo of The Ivy - London, United Kingdom. Pavlova, second time ive tried this particular dessert, first time here. Im afraid this blows Joe Forte in YVR out of the water.
Photo of The Ivy - London, United Kingdom. Liver, best ive ever had. Try it with some spicy mustard on the side.

f2RwSybFwVjZZAhlJe60Ig.text: A true taste of London. I'm a typical Monday afternoon the place is busy, you'll see locals having wine or champagne with their lunch. The menu is interesting it offers a variety of items. I like that they have fish of the day. I wouldn't recommend the shrimp and avocado appetizer. The carrot soup amazing, I liked without yogurt. The st Germaine Champagne cocktail is lovely.

cgPglm5utDvwcfU1g_Q3Kg.text: Very cool vibe but the food was meh. I ordered the fish of the day and it was not good at all. The fish was definitely not fresh. My husband had the filet and it was mediocre. I wouldn't recommend people to come to this restaurant to eat, only to grab drinks at the bar.

5JqO8x7s6PaZesTmGoHs2A.text: We randomly came here for breakfast.  It was an upscale joint with upscale food.  My husband got the full english and I got the smoked salmon.  Best full english and smoked salmon we have had.  Service was a little slow so it made breakfast become more of a dinner feel.

photos.caption: Photo of The Ivy - London, United Kingdom

lnQL8zzdj5Jnc-fD8gMMrA.text: Really fun restaurant, excellent food,hip environment, there was a DJ playing great music. It was packed so I suggest having a reservation.

NCxksgLMjz0eYdWQYUT1xQ.text: This was my favorite dinner in London! Everything was so delicious. My sea bass was the most unique flavor I've ever had with fish and it was delicious. The honeycomb sundae, although very simple, was also one of the best desserts I've ever had. Service was great and prices were comparable to the quality of food and service.

photos.caption: Photo of The Ivy - London, United Kingdom. Burrata appetizer, very good
Photo of The Ivy - London, United Kingdom. The best sea bass ever
Photo of The Ivy - London, United Kingdom. Lamb was excellent

Q6nHd_0EWSusY4S5KJyyJw.text: Perfect place in London for a classic lunch in Covent Garden. Yummy and nice. Classy / casual. The food was delicious and the service was on point. Definitely recommended.

photos.caption: Photo of The Ivy - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Ivy - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Ivy - London, United Kingdom

V0iynhg4Es4cx_8v_bmK_A.text: I had a review of this saved for like two years so I'm finally posting itI enjoy restaurants in London especially because they have a dedicated Vegetarians menu (yes not an after thought or yes we can remove the meat and give make it vegetarian for the same freaking price)The Ivy is right next to Covent Garden so you have plenty of restaurants to choose from, they have delicious food and its priced affordably, more like $$ and not $$$ as advertised. I had the soup and gnocchi both of which were good, they didnt have a chocolate cake on the menu or else i would've tried that as well

d7Vbq4E3t5P_j3EjxK_unQ.text: Fantastic, Classic restaurant - make a reservation now! Our entire meal was perfection from start to finish and the service was pure perfection.  Start with a cocktail at the 100 year old bar and then make sure, after dinner, to save room for dessert and tea or coffee, it's well worth it!

JXFMwjrWIIHTZIS4tNC-UA.text: The Ivy was absolutely stunning. The outdoor seating area was beautiful, and their Christmas tree was gorgeous. The service was excellent, and our server was a hilarious and fabulous man from Thailand. The food was unique and delicious. The duck salad was stunning. Apparently, the Peach Bellini was delicious. I highly suggest trying this restaurant if you find yourself at Covent Garden.

photos.caption: Photo of The Ivy - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Ivy - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Ivy - London, United Kingdom

E3urZuiHDZ9WTfq2ok4JAA.text: We came here right when The Ivy opened so we could catch our early flight. The place just opened at 8 am on a Saturday morning and we were the only customers there the whole time. The interior was beautiful and I can imagine this is the place to be for weekend brunch if we only get here at 11am! The location, food and decor are definitely to be sought after.We ordered the crumpet with a delicious concoction of marmite, honey and butter (as an American, this is the way to eat marmite!). The crumpet was delicious with the right amount of crunch and soft, chewy batter goodness. At the waiters recommendation we had the eggs, avocado and tomato with sesame dressing. This was absolutely amazing and I am going to attempt to recreate this at home. I definitely like this location better than LA and the over hype of the location.

photos.caption: Photo of The Ivy - London, United Kingdom. Crumpet with a delicious mix of marmite, honey and butter.
Photo of The Ivy - London, United Kingdom. Egg, avocado and tomato

eEhKg8U4qFGksIHSr4w8fw.text: We were excited to try the "original" Ivy, and were, frankly, disappointed - much more by the service than by the food.The food was good...not outstanding, but very good.  Among us, we had a tuna sashimi starter, which was by far the best dish of the night.  A basil gnocci was the other standout.Our main dishes were pretty ho-hum...I got a chicken curry dish off the "classics" menu which was good but nothing spectacular.  Wifey had a shepherd's pie which was also good.The service, which in London high-end restaurants I expect to be outstanding, left much to be desired.  No one explained specials.  We had to beg to have drink orders taken, and ended up giving up.  We finally flagged someone down to take our orders, who said "someone" would be by to take drink orders...apparently that "someone" got lost on the way to our table.By the time I grabbed someone else, our food started to arrive, so I can't comment on the bartender's mixology talents.The wife and I love London, but probably won't be back to the Ivy given the stiff competition in this "foodie heaven" of a city.

X6OEqQD4BSgaSzuD9qyoqw.text: The family enjoyed The Ivy beginning with cocktails, appetizer, entree, wine and dessert. The place is upscale, service is attentive and not a long wait. Good place for a celebration. A ver special time.

9r3Zn1wN6wmYNTGz00tOVQ.text: So this was my first ever trip to the original Ivy. I did think before hand that it is probably quite overhyped. It did feel a little rah rah but gosh the food!!!!!  We started with the burata. I am quite burata obsessed at the moment and boy was this good burata. So creamy and flavoursome. We also tried the popcorn shrimp which was amazing - such a non greasy experience for an essentially greasy treat. But then came the highlight - the shepherds pie. Wow wow wow. It was amazing / the flavour was so rich but never too rich - it was a perfect balance of I can't stop eating this without being too much. And it wasn't that expensive considering!

photos.caption: Photo of The Ivy - London, United Kingdom. Mum burata
Photo of The Ivy - London, United Kingdom. London's best shelpherd's pie

HAKAINHP7fSZxB4RpUoq-g.text: I went to a corporate event at The Ivy a few months ago. The service and the food were both excellent. The menu was set by my supplier so I didn't get to choose much but nonetheless the presentation and quality of food was excellent.

o5UFnzd9kCItwaCOuWYagg.text: The food at the Ivy has improved alot in the past year in my opinion. It's all fairly standard British / bistro type but I haven't been disappointed yet. The shepherds pie is awesome, one of the best i've ever had and the duck and watermelon salad is also very good. We had a fantastic blueberry meringue pie a while ago but it wasn't on the menu last time. The chocolate fondant is good but better without the ice cream which is a bit plastic and too sweet.

dwr2toP7blkUzcjOuOXHag.text: What a great venue. My wife and I loved the food and the service was second to none. The portions were very decent and I can't wait to return.

YsQkeI5DyEOT0uhm_i2dlw.text: Managed to get a table for four after many months of trying and re-arranging diaries. The atmosphere is friendly and the staff are attentive but not over the top. There is a buzz about the place and expectations are high. Fell into the trap of watching every person entering the room to see if they were a celebrity! Sad I know..The food was good with no real highs considering the prices. The Blythburgh belly of pork was delicious. The wines were good but as you expect a bit pricey. All in all a great evening. Would like to see an amuse bouche or something to add wow factor. Worth a visit.

VlAiIxs-8i4Uys_GsADTDg.text: I've been to The Ivy four times in the past year and I haven't enjoyed it once. The food is bland, bland, bland and as far as I can see, the way they give it that quality feel in the mouth is by lacing it with as much butter as it's chemically possible to contain without oozing the stuff neat. The surrounds are all right and the atmosphere OK, although it's full of tourists. Why do celebrities still go there, as the indubitably do? I guess it's the same reason as they do all the other things they're supposed to do - behave badly, divorce a lot, be photographed against their will (yeah, right). Why do the food critics continue to rave about The Ivy? I wish I knew. It may be Emperor's new clothes syndrome. Or it may be they're sheep like the cee-lebs. Or (and I increasingly believe this) that they don't really like food, whcih is, after all, the British way. The Ivy is a dull restaurant and the food makes me feel sick. Think about it while you THINK you're having a great time. Does this taste of anything? Or is it mouthful after mouthful of fatty grey?

WNznTyXdsN7F_AgctgpHTw.text: I have eaten in the 'world renowned' Ivy on many occassions the last time on Saturday and I really don't know what the fuss is all about! I find the atmosphere to be dull and subdued with people scared to talk above a whisper. The food is traditional British fayre and although my shepherds pie was nice it was nowhere near what I would expect for the price. As with regards celebrity spotting, I have seen one or two 'Z classers' lurking about but nothing to write to 'Heat' about! Save your cash and go somewhere with a bit of life!

mzn44cON5qzNmutocIL5Jw.text: Came here for dinner with a friend after complaining that there was no good food anywhere in London!  It has a very 'British' atmosphere.  The food was good, although expensive.   The dinning area is dark and quiet, but I had a nice meal.

QLvOYltMISUtTNAlt8o-Ew.text: Definitely a restaurant to try before you die. I was surprised at how down to earth the place was when I visited despite seeing some well-known faces even on a Thursday afternoon. I loved it but who wouldn't love such a place when you have celebs nearby, fab food and you're not paying! I was lucky enough to be taken as a treat by my bosses so I may well have had a different view if I had to pay my way. Two things of note - apart from who is on the next table - is that the food is very simple fare but cooked to perfection and the service outstanding. A great way to spend an afternoon or evening. If I had to put it down for something, it would be the decor, I found it a bit old fashioned but that's just my opinion - well worth a visit and make sure you have some champers to start!

QlxBdU-kxNgAAPrNEJQm1w.text: The Ivy is really not that expensive and it has a good atmosphere, its relaxed and unpretentious. i will have to say that the food is really not that amazing. i have been more impressed with the food in local gastro pubs than here. You can really tell that a lot of the food is pre prepared but all in all it is of a good standard. you are mainly paying for the experience of being at the Ivy. Worthwhile going to but dont set your sights too high. I will say that the service is really good and the staff are plesent and attentive.

xRTsGkYmC4In6Azs4qP36Q.text: I love this restaurant. The food is always fresh and tasty, the service is excellant and the atmosphere lively. It is great value for what it is and perfect for any type of celebration. I can recommend any of the following dishes - shepherds pie, burger, steak, Bang Bang Chicken, any of the fish, chocolate pudding, treacle pudding. My parents have loved, my clients love it, my gorlfriend loves it. So do it, treat yourself, book it for your birthday and eat in one the consistently good restaurants in London.

4CNFHoKcbny8Zs345e8Rcw.text: What with all the hype and hot air that is written about this place - it wouldn't be a personal choice of mine to dine here - infact I would purposely steer clear. However I went to a works do in the upstairs function room and I really enjoyed myself. The service was excellent and the food was (as it should be) beautifully prepared and really delicious.

1IdaNwGa42vG3m0VGq2N5g.text: One of the swankiest places to eat in London. It is a hot favourite with the rich and famous too, so you will usually spot a celeb or two during your dining experience. The food is exceptional and the service is really very good. They also have a bar area that you can book if tere is no space in the restaurant. All in all it is a great experience and you should go at least once, but make it for a special occasion because it's not cheap!

Jq71q0S3VyoEM9oHbcgdIw.text: I've had some splendid meals here. despite the storied history and showbiz clientele, the wait staff are friendly and not at all snooty. The place feels old, in a good way, and the English comfort food warms the heart of any Northern European (people favouring refined or light food might struggle a little). I took a Californian friend and she didn't get it at all, but head there with a good honest English lass and you'll have a good old lunch or dinner. I'd even suggest you pretend to be showbiz there - by that i mean take a 2.5 hour lunch, drink a bottle of wine, and take time to savour life for a change. if you are determined to also drive to the restaurant, one of the world's most expensive parking garages is round the corner.

mjYztZALf82HglqXgjz0_Q.text: We went as a birthday surprise with good friends and I must admit were prepared to be disappointed and in fact were pleasantly surprised. We had a last lunchtime sitting which made it a bit more relaxed as it emptied as we found it noisey and with tables very close together not good for an intimate meal. The food was good and not overly expensive but equally it was not outstanding. It is one of those places you do once in your life! We spent £60 per head for two courses with drinks and wine.

Os8mXQLXwh0919qk2eqd5Q.text: I think people place to much emphasis on this place for being about celebrities rather than good good. The food is lovely and I didnt think it was too overpriced. I have spend more in other london resturants.

-pl8E23iTlqYRdJRSvYv5g.text: A good time has always been had by all whenever I've visited this place. Stylish, well presented and welcoming from the moment you meet the doorman. The food is good hearty filling food. I've not had room for a dessert each time because the main course portions have been so filling, but my friends swear by them. Maybe I should skip the starter for a dessert next time. It can be difficult getting a table if you want to go at peak times, but midweek dinners or early evenings have always suited me fine and it hasn't been difficult to get a reservation then. Not too expensive for a top restaurant.

zDys1D3-KQ5dQXYeVR6ybA.text: The doorman here tells you all you need to know about this place. He is stylish and suave and immediately makes you feel welcome. As soon as you walk in the same class exudes throughout everything they do. The food is delicious and the wine is actually quite interesting given that they could probably sell anything. If you dont save room for dessert you are missing a trick - they have a way with chocolate which you ignore at your peril

f5O98RFoKgmmWT-uzx5Bsw.text: I was impressed with the service and cleanliness of this restaurant. The prices weren't bad and the food was really good. It was a great place for me and a friend to go for lunch. Will definately go there again. Didn't see any celebs though not that I care. I was more concerned with my tummy ;)

ZwZ5Hc8ZOtzOr71Rn4G5Zg.text: Lovely food, just cant say its bad at all, because its not - Its near perfect. Very busy but not as formal as they would like to make out. Great for corporate functions and to impress someone. If youre posh or like to pretend you are, or have lots of money or like to pretend you have, or always impress or like to try to impress, then The Ivy is one of THE places to go in London.

-sxsDDaUBPoR5OaNRepw9g.text: this was a very reasonable dinner (£100 for 2, including before dinner drinks and glass of wine with dinner) and not at all what i expected for a London dining experience. it has the appearance of posh and high end with the door man, the coat clerk and an almost all male wait staff, but i would say that almost half of the diners were wearing jeans - not what i expected at all, i even put on a dress and high heels for the occasion! with wood floors and tightly spaced tables, the ambiance was cracking with a crowded room of guests- more Chicago steakhouse then a quiet no music pub or afternoon tea room. i was told in advance to go for the comfort food items, so as it was Good Friday, i had the haddock with chips and a side of steamed spinach - it was all excellent.... was talked into dessert, a peanut parfait, and that was great too. with so many restaurants to try out in London, i may not be back for awhile, but i will recommend.

TPC8tyKf5eqHazgO0bncAQ.text: This is actually not a bad place to eat, but its not the best food in London. The person who designed the table layout has done a good job at packing you in. There is no space left unused. Food is average to good. There is this whole celeb spotting fever whenever you go with the chance of being 'papped' outside. On this visit is was John Snow (Newsreader) and Christopher Biggins (all round entertainer)

lE9JYZqGemCcDB-PKTiFYA.text: It's a really good and comfortable place, and that's why people like it, relaxed, efficient friendly service, quite a variety of food from sausages, corn beef hash, to caviar and lobster.Yes there are celebs, but they are off to the Wolsey and other places these days as well, so perhaps not the concentration of celebs as in the past.But who needs them, it's just a good place to be.Sometimes spare seats in the bar just as they open in the evening(5.30?)Got to go at least once.

S0O8v-9X7l8VF07nmJeZiQ.text: We visited the Ivy for Sunday lunch and not surprisingly had the Roast Beef. The meat was perfectly cooked, melt in the mouth! The veg was okay but the roast potatos were very average. The waiting staff were fantastic and the whole experience very relaxing. Definitely worth a visit.

vMKSxcWP5MkygHOuyq0FHQ.text: I hate the whole celebrity spotting thing and detest the go to a place because it's popular yet I still find myself wanting to return to The Ivy because whenever I've been here, they are always polite and treat you with the same courtesy I'd imagine they give everyone. I haven't found it too difficult to actually go here, with the trick being either a lunch time sitting, or an early or late evening sitting that's not the weekend. That way, you get to enjoy the clean fresh flavours of all their food, and friendly service without the waiting list or the crazy booking times that everyone seems to mention. Fair enough if you want a prime time meal, but it's not that hard to get otherwise. Food is always great quality, served with decent portions and I never feel pressured to go for something that I don't want to have.

2ktR388XwiR9OuHlEQ8KAQ.text: The place to be seen for celebrities & media luvvies cultivated by a savvy management team. A friend of mine was CEO of a top advertising agency and was called to be asked if he could dine there more often as he was notable by his absence! Kinda sums up the whole place. If you not on the list, the best you will get is Sunday, early evening. Otherwise its nigh on impossible to get a table for 6 months. Eclectic & extensive menu that meanders a bit - British staples (shepherds pie, devilled kidneys, fish & chips) sit alongside curries, sushi, pastas & burgers. Food is OK and always reminds me of school/home cooking! I must say though that when I've been with kids, the staff have been excellent.

SxfaJQQFD9Hc82nE4xJ7nw.text: I have been to The Ivy just once and absolutely loved eating there. Admittedly, my boyfriend did propose to me in between the main course and dessert (my memory of the honeycomb ice cream is fuzzy to say the least) so I may reasonably be accused of being biased, but I am capable of criticism even under romantic circumstances. On that note - as locations for popping the question go, this was pretty spectacular. We're not a glamorous couple, so the good quality, relaxed and unobtrusive nature of the restaurant was perfect. Having taken the time to plan ahead and book months in advance is a lovely gesture and we somehow managed to get a table on a Saturday night. I was impressed from the start. The service was impeccable, the decor unassuming, clean (but not pristine or false) and ever so slightly quirky. The tables look quite close to one another when you first walk in, but once seated, you don't really notice and unless you purposefully eavesdrop, you're not really aware of other people's conversations. The food was fantastic. Refreshingly unpretentious, perfectly cooked and with ample portions. There is something to suit everyone here and my soon-to-be-fiance and I had a slightly posh version of fish and chips and bangers and mash for our mains. Ok, the fish was actually seared yellow fin tuna, but you get the idea Our starters were Eggs Benedict and Bang Bang Chicken, both of which I can highly recommend. And price wise it was pretty impressive too. Not cheap, obviously, but providing you don't have a taste for lobster or oysters you can get by with a reasonable bill at the end of the night. I believe the website includes menu prices if you want to work it out more precisely. We didn't spot any celebs though.but then we were enjoying ourselves too much to notice or care.

533WyO-ClBlML8VhWL7-rg.text: Totally disappointed.I visited The Ivy on 22nd August, I look back now and realise I was expecting a dining experience, and that all the restaurant is, is an eating place with a reputation for celebs being there. Have celebs no idea of quality of food? Obviously not, our starter of bang bang chicken was ok, thats all that can be said, my husband had the steak pie, which inside was watery gravy with meat, mash which was grey, and veg that was shrivelled. I had kedgeree which was dreadfull, so much so that I complained. I had been looking forward to a dining expreience to add to many other fantastic meals I have had in beautiful restaurants. The Ivy is nothing more than a name above a door.

wBg_RWor3kx9-OxDoBHn3g.text: Very nice food which is important. I find it quite a twisty turny affair on entrance but once seated, everything seems well organised and efficient. I think there is very much an atmosphere of diners enjoying a secluded and private dining experience. Nice interior too. Very cosy and intimate.. :)

Fns80k4DrQnmwRvSXRrOvA.text: The Ivy - is all about service, yes it does cost more than your normal high end restaurant it's the relaxing but old style decor is part of charm and the food is superb and you will be suitably filled by the end of your meal - for the costs you are waited upon which is what you would expect from such a prestigous establishment. I would definatley recommend to those who love great food and service.

A4RkrIXTSvZTxnKqgOG1Zg.text: The service in The Ivy was fantastic, very attentive staff - nothing was too much trouble for them. The atmosphere and decor are great and everyone in our party of 4 really enjoyed themselves. The food was good and not overly expensive but I have to say I have had better food for the same sort of price in other London restaurants. Still, The Ivy is one of those places you've got to try at least once in your lifetime, for the wonderful service if nothing else!!

5--wDmwgkrBSuX5lXY4VNQ.text: Loved the atmosphere and decor here. From walking through the door we were provided with excellent service, dont think it would be a good idea to come here just because celebs do, as we didnt see any. This was however, not our reason for wanting to go. Having already perused the menu online we were surprised at the nice prices that came the surprisingly informal dishes. We went for lunch and therefore we sampled the more informal dishes. I has corned beef hash for example. It was priced at £9.25 and I really enjoyed it. The portion was so large I had to give my boyfriend some. We treated ourselves to half a bottle of chablis, which cost £17.50 - not worth it, dont bother. Sometimes I feel a bit cheapo picking the lowest priced wine but unless you are a wine conasseur you may not notice the difference as the wine is chilled to within an inch of its life and therefore could have been any old plonk and I wouldnt have noticed!! Would definately go again, but would pick cheaper wine as we didnt see the benefit of picking a posh one.

O_vknT40hkboYyGgzj2C7w.text: I recently went to the Ivy for lunch it was very pleasant however, the decor was a bit dated and scruffy, I guess that's the look and feel of the place. The food was nice... nothing out of this world, but I must say the Rhubarb desert and Peach Bellini's were very good. The service was very good so over all a good experience.

ZXCRuXGL9X9ns38y0ky0vw.text: The best service around. Not fussy but attentive. It is always busy and is not as stuck up as one would think. It is good to not worry about the price so you can have a good time  so save up. Try to get an 8-10 in the evening time slot to do some celeb spotting. Every celeb from A  Z grade soap fodder. When I was there the tiny man from 'Top Gear' was having a burger. Very tiny too! Him, not the burger.

hmOvfhMPHhzCJDmAUsuk-Q.text: If I were over that way and wanted to make sure I got a good meal, I would not hesitate to return her.

f5fFelqL_I2oXPmSZBe3Rg.text: I had a wonderful tuna sashimi starter (with a tiny bit too much horseradish for my taste, but I just put it to the side) and a rib-eye steak that filled my entire plate. The steak was more medium than medium rare, but it was absolutely delicious and full of charred beefy flavor. Bearnaise sauce was creamy and perfect. Everyone helped me polish off the bowl of frites on the side - salty and crisp. The elderflower jelly with fruit suspended within was also decorated with gold leaf - possibly excessive but it went very well with the atmosphere of quiet luxury that they cultivate.

Fellow diners seemed to be either awfully pretentious, or overawed due to the 'celeb' reputation that the Ivy carries. 21kR7VsZdK1_wFOryQYAtA.text: To be honest, I only went to this place to impress my friends. However, I have to say I was pleasantly surprised. OK yes, it did cost a bit more than I expected but it was absolutely worth every penny. The service was great, the food was delicious and I was very impressed to their paid attention to detail.

pzPodKU2bjNVtzw-3U6z5Q.text: This is one of my favourite restaurants in London. It gets everything right. Not just the food, although you can believe the hype - it is sublime- but the ambiance, the decor, the staff, and most importantly, the way the customer is treated. From the moment the friendly doorman outside lets you in, your exceptional dining experience begins. It is a hard task for a place with so much history to be contemporary, but The Ivy easily pulls it off. Their menu takes the best of British and ever so slightly updates the dishes, adding a subtle European or Asian influence here and there. I have been here for my 21st, and then my second 21st. (otherwise known as my 30th), as well as other families birthdays. Here's the thing, it is not intimidating, it is not snooty, and you don't have to be famous in order to get a table. You don't even have to be rich - the dishes are actually not that expensive. Everyone is treated the same and given the same first rate service. Once you are seated, by way of the bar and a cocktail to start you off, you are spoilt for choice with the extensive menu. The dishes, for the most part, remain the same, but there are also monthly or seasonal additions, as well as a very comprehensive vegan and vegetarian menu. I usually go for one of the cheaper bottles of french white, and will hit the ground running on the starters with either the Bang-Bang Chicken, or Spinach, Avocado and Roquefort Salad. But I mainly come here for the much talked about Salmon Fishcake with sauteed spinach and a creamy sorrel sauce. It is simply one of the best meals that I have ever eaten. Again, it is not expensive. This meal is £15.75 and I have never been able to finish it because it is so substantial and rich. My dad usually goes for the Shepherds Pie, or Ivy Hamburger, both dishes he can never finish either. Trust me, we are not a family with small appetites! If you can save room for pudding (I plan for The Ivy by starving myself for the whole day so that I can fit in 3 courses), I would go for the sticky toffee pudding. It is a shame that the Eton Mess is no longer on the menu - a concoction of smashed meringue and raspberry sauce. Still, the other puddings more than make up for its loss. I hope that whoever goes to The Ivy enjoys themselves as much as I have done when I'm there.
